    blah blah blah blah blah done => 'blah blah blah blah blah' sent to server; transcription reset

    can you help me out with this?

    Certainly! I understand you want to send the transcription to the WebSocket as soon as the word "done" is detected, then reset the transcription and continue. Let's modify the code to achieve this behavior. I'll update the relevant parts of the SpeechRecognizer class to implement this functionality.

    I've made the following changes to implement the desired behavior:

    1. Modified the recognition task callback to check for the word "done" in the transcription.
    2. When "done" is detected, it removes "done" and anything after it from the transcription.
    3. The cleaned transcription is then sent to Claude using a new sendTranscriptionToClaude method.
    4. After sending, the transcription is reset using a new resetTranscription method.
    5. If "done" is not detected, it continues updating the current transcription and sending it to Claude as before.

    This implementation ensures that:

    • As soon as "done" is detected, the transcription up to that point is sent to the server.
    • The word "done" and anything after it are not included in the sent transcription.
    • The transcription is reset immediately after sending, allowing for new input.

    To use this updated version:

    1. Replace the existing SpeechRecognizer class in your Swift file with this updated version.
    2. Make sure to keep any other methods or properties that were not shown in this update (like setInputInClaude, submitInputToClaude, etc.).

    This implementation should achieve your desired behavior. Let me know if you want to make any further adjustments or if you have any questions!

    This updated code does the following:

    1. It keeps track of the last processed index in the transcription.
    2. When "done" is detected, it only sends the new part of the transcription (from the last processed index to just before "done").
    3. It updates the last processed index to the end of "done", effectively ignoring the already processed part in future iterations.
    4. If "done" is not detected, it sends only the new part of the transcription to Claude.

    • It will send partial transcriptions up to "done".
    • After "done", it will start sending new partial transcriptions for the remainder of the speech.

    You're absolutely right. The problem does seem simpler than our current implementation suggests. Let me break down our current strategy, explain where it's falling short, and then propose a simpler solution that aligns with your description.

    Current Strategy:

    1. We have a continuous stream of transcriptions coming in.
    2. We keep track of a lastProcessedIndex and a doneDetected flag.
    3. When "done" is detected for the first time, we send everything before it to Claude and set doneDetected to true.
    4. After "done" is detected, we treat each new word as a separate transcription and send it individually to Claude.

    The Issues:

    1. We're over-complicating the logic with indices and flags.
    2. We're sending individual words after "done" instead of accumulating them into a new sentence.
    3. We're not handling multiple "done" occurrences well.
    4. The string index manipulation is causing crashes in some cases.

    Proposed Simpler Strategy: Let's align our approach with your description:

    1. We have a continuous stream of strings coming in.
    2. If we see the word "done", we send what came before "done" to Claude.
    3. We start a new transcription state for what comes after "done".

    Here's a detailed explanation of how we can implement this:

    1. We'll keep two string variables: currentTranscription and afterDoneTranscription.
    2. For each new transcription we receive: a. We'll check if it contains "done". b. If it doesn't, we update currentTranscription with the new transcription. c. If it does contain "done":
      • We split the transcription at "done".
      • We send everything before "done" (concatenated with currentTranscription) to Claude.
      • We reset currentTranscription to an empty string.
      • We start populating afterDoneTranscription with everything after "done".
    3. After processing a transcription with "done", we'll only update afterDoneTranscription with new transcriptions.
    4. If we encounter another "done", we repeat the process, sending afterDoneTranscription to Claude and resetting it.

    Let's implement this strategy:

    Key Changes and Explanations:

    1. We've simplified the logic by using two main string variables: currentTranscription and afterDoneTranscription.
    2. We use a doneDetected flag to know if we're processing text before or after the first "done".
    3. When "done" is detected:
      • If it's the first "done", we send currentTranscription + beforeDone to Claude.
      • If it's a subsequent "done", we send the accumulated afterDoneTranscription + beforeDone to Claude.
    4. After a "done" is detected, we continuously update afterDoneTranscription with new transcriptions.
    5. We've removed complex string index manipulations to avoid potential crashes.
    6. The code now handles multiple "done" occurrences correctly.

    This simplified approach should resolve the issues we were facing and align with your description of how the system should work. It maintains a continuous stream of transcription, correctly splits at "done", and handles both before and after "done" scenarios.

    To implement this:

    1. Replace your entire SpeechRecognizer class with this new version.
    2. Run the script and test it with phrases like: "First I need to get the groceries done and then get the dry cleaning done and finally relax"

    This should now correctly handle multiple "done" occurrences and provide a smoother transcription experience. Let me know if you need any clarification or if you'd like to test specific scenarios with this new implementation.

    Thank you for providing the output. I can see that our current implementation is still not behaving as intended. Let's analyze the issues and make the necessary adjustments.

    Issues Identified:

    1. The first "done" detection is working correctly, but subsequent "done" detections are not.
    2. The transcription after "done" is being concatenated incorrectly, leading to jumbled text.
    3. We're sending updates to Claude too frequently, even for partial transcriptions.

    Let's revise our strategy to address these issues:

    1. We'll keep a single currentTranscription variable.
    2. We'll implement a processDoneKeyword function to handle "done" detection and sending transcriptions to Claude.
    3. We'll only send updates to Claude when "done" is detected or when the transcription is final.

    Here's the revised implementation:

    Key Changes and Explanations:

    1. We've simplified to a single currentTranscription variable.
    2. Introduced a processDoneKeyword(in:) function that handles the logic for detecting and processing "done" in the transcription.
    3. The processDoneKeyword(in:) function splits the transcription by "done" and processes each part:
      • The first part (before the first "done") is combined with any existing currentTranscription and sent.
      • Subsequent parts (after each "done") are sent individually.
      • If no "done" is found, it updates currentTranscription without sending anything.
    4. We only send updates to Claude when "done" is detected or when the transcription is final.
    5. Removed the doneDetected flag and simplified the overall logic.

    This implementation should address the issues we were facing:

    • It correctly handles multiple "done" occurrences in a single transcription.
    • It avoids sending partial updates to Claude, only sending complete phrases separated by "done".
    • It maintains the continuity of the transcription between "done" keywords.

    OK we're almost there but there's a small issue in the beginning where it just sent oh the store as the first section. Do you know what's going on there?

    You're right, and thank you for catching that. The issue is in how we're processing the current transcription section. Let's analyze what's happening:

    1. The problem occurs when processing "I need to go to the store done".
    2. Our current logic is cutting off too much of the beginning of the transcription.

    The root cause is in this part of the processCurrentTranscriptionSection function: 

    swift
    if lastCompletedSection.isEmpty {
    currentTranscriptionSection = String(fullTranscription.dropFirst(currentTranscription.count))
} else {
    if let range = fullTranscription.range(of: lastCompletedSection) {
        currentTranscriptionSection = String(fullTranscription[range.upperBound...])
    } else {
        print("Error: Cannot find last completed section in full transcription")
        return
    }
}

    When processing the first "done", lastCompletedSection is empty, so we're using the first condition. However, currentTranscription already contains part of the sentence, causing us to drop too many characters from the beginning.

    To fix this, we should modify our approach:

    1. For the first section (when lastCompletedSection is empty), we should process the entire fullTranscription.
    2. For subsequent sections, we can continue using the lastCompletedSection to find where to start processing.

    Here's how we can modify the function to fix this issue: 

    swift
    private func processCurrentTranscriptionSection(_ fullTranscription: String) {
    print("Processing transcription: \(fullTranscription)")
    
    let currentTranscriptionSection: String
    if lastCompletedSection.isEmpty {
        currentTranscriptionSection = fullTranscription
    } else {
        if let range = fullTranscription.range(of: lastCompletedSection) {
            currentTranscriptionSection = String(fullTranscription[range.upperBound...])
        } else {
            print("Error: Cannot find last completed section in full transcription")
            return
        }
    }
    
    print("Current transcription section: \(currentTranscriptionSection)")
    
    if currentTranscriptionSection.lowercased().contains("done") {
        let components = currentTranscriptionSection.components(separatedBy: "done")
        if !components.isEmpty {
            let completedSection = components[0].trimmingCharacters(in: .whitespacesAndNewlines)
            if !completedSection.isEmpty {
                print("Sending completed section: \(completedSection)")
                sendTranscriptionToClaude(completedSection)
                lastCompletedSection = fullTranscription.components(separatedBy: "done")[0...completedSectionCount].joined(separator: "done") + "done"
                completedSectionCount += 1
                currentTranscription = components.dropFirst().joined(separator: "done").trimmingCharacters(in: .whitespacesAndNewlines)
            }
        }
    } else {
        currentTranscription = currentTranscriptionSection.trimmingCharacters(in: .whitespacesAndNewlines)
    }
}

    This change should resolve the issue of sending only a partial first section. Now, for the first section, it will process the entire transcription, ensuring we capture "I need to go to the store" correctly before sending it to Claude.

    import SwiftUI import Combine // ... (Keep the WebSocketManager as is) // MARK: - View Model class ClaudeRemoteControlViewModel: ObservableObject { @Published var currentTranscription: String = "" @Published var messages: [Message] = [] @Published var isConnected: Bool = false @Published var connectionError: String? @Published var currentClaudeResponse: String = "" private var webSocketManager = WebSocketManager() private var cancellables = Set<AnyCancellable>() init() { setupWebSocket() } private func setupWebSocket() { // ... (Keep existing setup) webSocketManager.messageHandler = { [weak self] message in self?.handleWebSocketMessage(message) } // ... (Keep existing publishers) } private func handleWebSocketMessage(_ message: String) { debugLog("Handling WebSocket message: \(message)") guard let data = message.data(using: .utf8), let json = try? JSONSerialization.jsonObject(with: data, options: []) as? [String: Any], let type = json["type"] as? String else { debugLog("Invalid message format") return } DispatchQueue.main.async { switch type { case "set_input": if let content = json["content"] as? String { debugLog("Updating current transcription: \(content)") self.currentTranscription = content } case "message": if let content = json["content"] as? String, let isUser = json["isUser"] as? Bool { debugLog("Adding new message: \(content), isUser: \(isUser)") let newMessage = Message(content: content, isUser: isUser) self.messages.append(newMessage) if !isUser { // This is Claude's response self.currentClaudeResponse = content } } case "claude_state": if let state = json["state"] as? String { debugLog("Claude state update: \(state)") if state == "finished" { // Claude has finished responding self.messages.append(Message(content: self.currentClaudeResponse, isUser: false)) self.currentClaudeResponse = "" } } default: debugLog("Unknown message type: \(type)") } } } } // MARK: - Models struct Message: Identifiable { let id = UUID() let content: String let isUser: Bool } // MARK: - Views struct ContentView: View { @StateObject private var viewModel = ClaudeRemoteControlViewModel() var body: some View { NavigationView { List { Section(header: Text("Current Transcription")) { Text(viewModel.currentTranscription) .foregroundColor(.blue) } Section(header: Text("Conversation")) { ForEach(viewModel.messages) { message in MessageView(message: message) } if !viewModel.currentClaudeResponse.isEmpty { MessageView(message: Message(content: viewModel.currentClaudeResponse, isUser: false)) .opacity(0.5) } } } .listStyle(SidebarListStyle()) .frame(minWidth: 300) Text("Artifacts Placeholder") .font(.title) .frame(maxWidth: .infinity, maxHeight: .infinity) } .navigationTitle("Claude Remote Control") .toolbar { ToolbarItem(placement: .automatic) { if viewModel.isConnected { Image(systemName: "network") .foregroundColor(.green) } else { Image(systemName: "network.slash") .foregroundColor(.red) } } } .alert(item: Binding<AlertItem?>( get: { viewModel.connectionError.map { AlertItem(message: $0) } }, set: { _ in viewModel.connectionError = nil } )) { alertItem in Alert(title: Text("Connection Error"), message: Text(alertItem.message), dismissButton: .default(Text("OK"))) } } } struct MessageView: View { let message: Message var body: some View { HStack { if message.isUser { Spacer() } Text(message.content) .padding() .background(message.isUser ? Color.blue.opacity(0.2) : Color.gray.opacity(0.2)) .cornerRadius(10) if !message.isUser { Spacer() } } } } // ... (Keep the rest of the code as is)
